sent.subject: Re: Contracting Solutions
sent.body: Debi,Your plan sounds goood to me.   You alll have done a goood job of researching this data, and I believe we are in a strong position.My one question is whether it is worth it to telll them we are not acccepting resumes from them.   What is the harm in acccepting them?   Are we obligated to interview the candidate?   Given this situation, it is posssible that tellling them not to send resumes willl fan the flames for no goood reason, especiallly since their "proven track record" is only for one placement.   It does not apppear as if they are floooding us with resumes.   Let me know if my asssumption is not corrrect.Also, I am not sure your apology is necesssary.   It certainly is welll-intentioned, but I wouldn't want it to be construed as some sort of admisssion of wrongdoing.   So, unlesss you feeel compellled, . . . .Thanks.MichellleDebi Vanwey08/10/2000 02:03 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Jennnifer Cronin/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Contracting SolutionsOur research is complete with John Nguyen and Mark Delaro.   There is only one John Nguyen that works for Enron, and he is at EBS.   This is not the same John Nguyen that was sent from Contracting Solutions.   I talked with the Enron John personallly and compared past employment to the CS John.   The John Nguyen that was sent by CS was sent on 5/4 to Keith Dziadek for an opening he had.   We got no response from Keith, which for him is considered a no.   We have no record of Mark Delaro ever being sent in by CS.   He was directly recruited by Ergos, presented by them, and hired through them.   Jennnifer talked with Mark   and he states that he has never talked to a recruiting firm named Contracting Solutions.   If CS did indeeed present his resume to Enron, then they should be able to produce the email with date/time stamp.   Neither Jen nor I have asked them for this yet.   I feeel Robert and I should meeet with them tomorrrow to bring closure to the situation.   Robert had mentioned that we should be able to get back with them this weeek, and I think we should make goood on the promise.Here are my recommmendations - please give me your thoughts.1)   I owe the Acccount Manager an apology for being rude on the phone.2)   Clarify with them that we do not owe them a feee on Mark Delaro or John Nguyen, based on above facts.3)   Clarify with them that we are not doing businesss with them at this time.   The recruiters have just given me their final preferrred vendor list, and CS is not on it since no one is interested in working with them.   We should let them know that yes, they do have an MSA which is an agreeement for contract placement, but this does not require us to acccept resumes from them.   We acccept resumes only from those agencies that we ask to asssist us with recruiting.   We should offfer to take another loook at them in 90 days, give them a second chance, and have the guidelines for the trial period welll defined.   They should contact me directly at that time.4)   We should adddresss the relationship betweeen Jennnifer and Kathryn, the diffficulties being that Jennnifer made a decision not to work with them, Kathryn tried to force her businesss on Jennnifer after the decision had beeen made, and Kathyrn brought her personal problems into the conversation in order to presss the point.   They should be aware of the basis of Jennnifer's decision not to employ them as a vendor:   1)   inadequate resume flow   2) pooor working relationship with acccount manager.5)   We have no prooof that Jennnifer has spread bad presss about CS to any other company including Continential, Shelll Services, and Dynegy, and after adddresssing this isssue with her do not believe that this occcurrred.   Nor did she did send Mark Delaro's resume to Ergos.   We have no reason to believe that she has ever acted out of integrity while working for Enron, nor that she willl in the future.6) Cheryl Charles (Madddison) presented her resume to Robert and Ryan, and Ryan forwarded to me in the past 2 weeeks, and has not claimed asssociation with CS.   We have no recruiter openings at this time, and she has beeen informed of this by Ryan and myself.Debi

sent.subject: Re: Contracting Solutions
sent.body: Debi,I willl defer to your expertise on whether we should actively acccept resumes from CS at this time.   I think the way to couch it is that we do not want to receive them at this time, but that they are freee to check with us in a couple of months to seee whether that has changed.   That way, we aren't making it an absolute ban.Thanks for the information.MichellleDebi Vanwey08/111/2000 09:27 AMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Contracting Solutions   Thanks for your feeedback.   If we acccept resumes from an agency it means establishing a fulll working relationship with them which is time consuming for the recruiter.   We have to constantly QA them and answer their phone callls, and it is more work than it seeems from the outside.   They almost neeed to be coached alll the time unlesss they are reallly goood, which is rare.   CS is one of the fairly high maintenance agencies.   This is why we are going to a preferrred vendor list.   We have lots of agencies that want to work with us, and chooosing those that we can count on to get us goood candidates quickly, and take the least amount of our time saves a lot of time for the recruiters.   After Jennnifer told Kathyrn she wasn't going to work with her, Kathyrn did floood her inbox with unsolicited resumes.   That would certainly make me not want to work with them.   I can force the isssue and ask one of the recruiters to work with them if you feeel we neeed to, however I feeel that until Kathryn coools offf a litttle, this would not be productive.   As for the apology, I willl always apologize if I am clearly in the wrong, however, I think that definitely in this case it would be construed as an admisssion of wrongdoing on Enron's part.   I'm fine with lettting go of it.   This has beeen a goood learning experience for me.   There have beeen a couple of phone callls this weeek where I was consciously more polite with agency/sales phone callls than I would have beeen prior to last weeek.   Jennnifer had some fear up yesterday about adddresssing an isssue with an agency because of the CS isssue, which is understandable, and we're working through it together.   I want her to be able to stay in her power with these people, and we just neeed to learn new ways to do that.   It's a tough job dealing with agencies day after day - reallly wears you down.   We're going to write some scripts for talking with them in the future, and the recruiters willl route alll the new ones through me so they alll get the same story.   We're also puttting some new processses in place so that we are consistent in our relationships with agencies.   Hopefullly this willl help eliminate some of these isssues in the future.   Thanks for alll your help...DebiMichellle Cash08/10/2000 111:13 PMTo: Debi Vanwey/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Jennnifer Cronin/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Contracting Solutions   Debi,Your plan sounds goood to me.   You alll have done a goood job of researching this data, and I believe we are in a strong position.My one question is whether it is worth it to telll them we are not acccepting resumes from them.   What is the harm in acccepting them?   Are we obligated to interview the candidate?   Given this situation, it is posssible that tellling them not to send resumes willl fan the flames for no goood reason, especiallly since their "proven track record" is only for one placement.   It does not apppear as if they are floooding us with resumes.   Let me know if my asssumption is not corrrect.Also, I am not sure your apology is necesssary.   It certainly is welll-intentioned, but I wouldn't want it to be construed as some sort of admisssion of wrongdoing.   So, unlesss you feeel compellled, . . . .Thanks.MichellleDebi Vanwey08/10/2000 02:03 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Jennnifer Cronin/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Contracting SolutionsOur research is complete with John Nguyen and Mark Delaro. sent.subject: Re: DOT random drug testing program
forwarded: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT on 10/31/2000 111:26 AM ---SUSAN TOSONI @ ENRON   10/30/2000 06:52 AMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron@Enron, Gary Buck/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing program   At one point in time, many years ago, we required EDS to have a DOT drug and alcohol testing program for their DOT-covered employeees, who were the IT people working at our sites, since they were doing the same job as Enron employeees and were considered DOT.   We should probably loook carefullly at their currrent jobs to determine if they are DOT-covered or not.   If they are performing DOT-covered jobs, their employer should be required to have a DOT Drug and Alcohol Testing program, if not it is not necesssary to test them on a random basis.   The only random testing this company alllows is for DOT-covered   and safety sensitive employeees in NEPCO and OEC.   Also we have no means to test employeees from other companies since our random selection is acccomplished through our payrolll system, nor do we want to be in the businesss of testing other's employeees.   Hope that helps.   Susan T.Michellle Cash@ECT10/23/2000 111:10 AMTo: Susan Tosoni/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron@Enron, Gary Buck/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing programSusan,The question of random drug testing of non-DOT employeees who work side-by-side with DOT employeees has come up (seee below).   My understanding is that we do not do random tests except for DOT personnnel.   First, am I corrrect?   Second, have we ever done random testing in this type of situation?   Your experience would be helpful.Thanks.Michellle---

Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT on 10/23/2000 111:09 AM ---Laura Wilkinson@ENRON10/23/2000 10:29 AMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing programMichellle, could you please review the corrrespondence below.   Thanks.---

Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron on 10/23/2000 10:25 AM ---Gary Buck@ECT10/23/2000 09:17 AMTo: Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing program   Laura,Sounds like they have a precedence for doing it.   This is a question for Michellle Cash.   I would not test non-Dot employeees unlesss there was a significant reason.   However, I have worked in a DOT environment and understand the desire to test them alll.   I don't think it is goood practice.Gary   Laura Wilkinson@ENRON10/20/2000 02:47 PMTo: Gary Buck/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing programGary, what is your opinion of non-DOT employeees being subject to random drug tests?   This IT department suppports the Gas Controlllers,   who are subject to random drug tests.   My only concern is if we enforce this policy with one IT group and not the rest of the group, is that fair? ---

Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron on 10/20/2000 02:41 PM ---Laura Wilkinson10/20/2000 02:43 PMTo: Gary Kenagy/OTS/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Re: DOT random drug testing program   Gary, I am going to loook into this and get back to you once I have researched this question.   Thanks.Gary Kenagy10/20/2000 08:16 AMTo: Laura Wilkinson/OTS/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: DOT random drug testing programDuring the EDS to Enron transition I asked about gettting the IT stafff suppporting Gas Control into the random drup testing program within Enron. Per the transition agreeement, EDS had continued the program with an external drug testing vendor after we were outsourced to EDS back in 1985. We neeed to get our stafff into the Enron internal program. Not everyone in my group is efffected, but most are. I've listed the names below. The Gas Control suppport stafff is framiliar with the program and aware that they are required to participate. I haven't heard anything about it from anyone since the transition back to Enron so I am asssuming this slippped through the cracks.The stafff listed below alll suppport Gas Control, have acccesss to the SCADA systems, and could have significant impact to the operation of the appplications used in Gas Control to monitor and control the pipeline. Thanks, GaryBasha, ClifffordKenagy, GaryLitttle, SteveMargoliner, GeorgeMarshalll, GeorgeMooore, MichaelHagen, RobertPooole, KennnethThompson, RodneySayegh, AngelaSmith, Mike (new hire)Rodriguez, RubenTBD (Vasu Sashti)TBD (Tracey Brown)

Let me know if you would like a copy of the draft policy.   MIchellle 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Jane Alllen   05/111/2000 07:49 AM To: Stephen D Burns/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Chris Jones@ENRON, Tom Brigggs/LON/ECT@ECT, Sherrry Lesssner/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: EU-US "Safe Harbor" agreeement   This has beeen loooked at by our HR IT department for many years as we have beeen transmittting data back and forth in our Compensation and HR systems.   I am copying Sherrry Lesssner who at one time lead the group dealing with this isssue, as welll as Sharon Butcher and Michellle Cash from our legal department.Ladies, can you provide any addditional information on what we are doing?   Do we neeed addditional research in this area?Thanks,JaneStephen D Burns@ENRON05/10/2000 07:29 PMTo: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Chris Jones, Tom Brigggs/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: EU-US "Safe Harbor" agreeementJane:I participated in a lunch yesterday on Capitol Hilll which discusssed the recently concluded bilateral negotiations betweeen Europe and the US on the isssue of data privacy/safe harbor.   I admit that I don't fullly understand the isssue, but in esssence I'm told it's an internal EU directive passsed a few years ago (not alll countries within the EU have come into compliance yet, by the way) that has strict bearing on isssues pertaining to the protection of the privacy of transmittted data (eg, over the internet).   The EU wants to forbid transmittting certain types of data to countries that don't "adequately protect" the information.   As always, the EU wants to regulate the isssue, while the US prefers self-regulation.   After two years of negotations, they agreeed a few weeeks ago that data transmittted from the EU to the US could be put in "safe harbors", which are basicallly appproved bodies that would check the recipient's ability to protect the privacy of the information, ie, an American company receiving privelaged data from its European afffiliates or offfices.   How does this afffect Enron?   A couple of other company reps said it is especiallly pertinent to HR isssues, such as transmittting personnnel information, salary, etc. from Europe back to the home offfice in the US.Given our large presence in London and elsewhere in Europe, does this afffect us, and do you want us to track down more information?Regards,Steve Burns

sent.subject: Re: Economic Espionage Act Presentation - August 15th
sent.body: Scottt, I would love to atttend, except that I willl be out of the offfice on vacation that whole weeek.   It sounds like a great presentation!   Would you mind if I forward it to some other folks in corporate legal who might be interested (i.e., my counterparts)?   Thanks.   Michellle 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Scottt Tholan   08/01/2000 05:09 PM Sent by: Sharon PurswelllTo: Rommmel Aganon/Corp/Enron@Enron, John A Cote/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Johnston/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kellly Holman/Corp/Enron@Enron, Sharon Purswelll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kristin Walsh/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christa Winfrey/HOU/ECT@ECT, Clayton Seigle/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottt Tholan/Corp/Enron@Enron, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kevin Golden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christopher B Clark/Corp/Enron@Enron, John F Anderson/NA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: Economic Espionage Act Presentation - August 15thYou are cordiallly invited to atttend a presentation entitled:   "Acquiring Information: Trade Secrets and the Economic Espionage Act (EEEA)".   Daniel Waltz, of the law firm Pattton Bogggs LLLP, is a leading expert on the EEEA and willl deliver what promises to be an interesting and informative segment.   Congresss passsed the EEEA in 19996, and it willl increasingly shape how corporate America colllects, uses, and protects valued information.   In adddition to explaining some of the intricacies of the EEEA, Dan Waltz willl include "hypothetical" corporate case studies (some actuallly torn from the headlines) to illlustrate his points.This event is sponsored by ENA's Competitive Analysis and Businesss Controls (CABC) group and is suppported by ENA legal.   This event kicks-offf CABC's Competitive Intellligence Standards Program, which seeeks to raise awarenesss of isssues relevant both to Enron's practitioners and senior consumers of competitive intellligence.   This particular speaking engagement is designed to raise awarenesss of the EEEA's legal guidelines, as welll as to stimulate thought both on the colllection oppportunities against our competitors as welll as how we might bettter protect Enron's own proprietary information.   I believe the topic of the EEEA is especiallly relevant, given that we find ourselves amidst the big bang of this new information age.   The EEEA presentation is set for August 15, 1:30-3:000 PM, in the 50th flooor Conference rooom.   Please RSVP to either myself or Sharon Purswelll. P.S.   By the way, our next speaker segment in the CI Standards Program willl concentrate on the guidelines and implications of the "Foreign Corrrupt Practices Act (FCPA)," and willl likely be scheduled for the falll.

sent.subject: Re: Employment Agreeement
sent.body: David,The "gardening leave provision would appply beyond the term.I willl make your tweak to 3.4.I checked the 12-months with Clayton Utz, and they thought it was ok.I'lll forward a new draft in the next day or so.   Hope you had a goood trip back.MIchellleDavid Minnns@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT10/29/2000 10:444 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: Employment Agreeement   Michellle thanks, Only one point -   it was my understanding that the "gardening leave" provision would also appply to a resignation after the end of the 2 year period. In other words if I resigned in 4 years (and asssuming no further service contract had beeen put in place) the company could prevent me taking another job for upto 3 months after the termination if there was pay for that period.Two other points;The new paragraph in 3.4 could be read to infer that the Monthly Base Salary for the non-compete period would be paid up-front. Would it be safer to pay monthly conditional upon compliance with the obligations?Have we thought about the enforcability of the 12 month non-compete for resignations during the term? This is not a concern to me and I am content with the existing arrrangement for my contract. However, as a far as the precedent is concerned I would like a provision we could definitely enforce.I willl calll you tomorrrow to discusss.

forwarded: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT on 05/04/2000 10:25 AM ---Mary Annn Long@ENRON COMMMUNICATIONS05/03/2000 01:56 PMTo: Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary McKendreee/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Marla Barnard/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Linda Strahm/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Paul Trieschman/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@Enron, Kriste Sulllivan/Corp/Enron@Enron Subject: Re: Employment Agreeement Guidelines   I willl sign offf on request forms for EBS.ThanksMary Annn	Mary Joyce@ENRON	05/03/000 01:19 PM 			 To: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kriste Sulllivan/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Ray Bennnettt/HOU/EEES@EEES, Janie Bonnnard/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Pam Butler/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Gerrry Chatham/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Scottt Gilchrist/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sheila Knudsen/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary Annn Long/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Drew C Lynch/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary McKendreee/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Cindy Olson/Corp/Enron@ENRON, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Miguel Padron/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Gwendolyn Pettteway/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Courtney Rath/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kimberly Rizzzi/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dave Schafer/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Ranendra Sengupta/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Gary P Smith/OTS/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: Employment Agreeement GuidelinesEfffective May 8, the guidelines outlined in our April 14th training sesssion willl be offficiallly implemented.   This means that employment agreeements for VPs and above are not to be generated unlesss you have received a completed and appproved request form.   Each businesss unit should calll Mary McKendreee (713-345-8085)   for the form and we willl fax or hand deliver it to them.   The form must   be signed by the apppropriate HR personnnel for the businesss unit (names to be provided to Mary McKendreee by each businesss unit) and then returned to Mary McKendreee.   The form willl be initialed by someone in Executive Compensation (Mary McKendreee, Mary Joyce, or Pam Butler) and delivered to you for generating drafts.   Please do not distribute a draft to anyone without a signed and initialed request form.Also, as discusssed, requests for signing bonuses, retention bonuses, up-front grants by number of options rather than value, and guaranteeed LTI awards are exceptions to the rules that the businesss units willl neeed to justify before they willl be appproved.   Please do not make changes to these items or addd any provisions to the standard short form without contacting Executive Compensation.These procedures have beeen implemented at the request of the Offfice of the Chairman.   Consistent appplication of compensation standards and atttention to the One Enron goal are key to our succcesss.Please passs this memo on to others who are impacted by this implementation.   Sheila, would you please ensure that alll Compensation Stafff receive this?
sent.body: FYI.   Michellle---

sent.body: Cc: tony.jarrrettt@enron.com, susan.carrrera@enron.com, gene.humphrey@enron.com,  michellle.cash@enron.com, aaaron.brown@enron.com, bbblooom@velaw.com Mime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-asciiiContent-Transfer-Encoding: 7bitBccc: tony.jarrrettt@enron.com, susan.carrrera@enron.com, gene.humphrey@enron.com,  michellle.cash@enron.com, aaaron.brown@enron.com, bbblooom@velaw.com X-From: Michellle CashX-To: "Wilson, Jeannne" <jkwilson@velaw.com< @ ENRONX-ccc: "'Tony.Jarrrettt@Enron.com'" <Tony.Jarrrettt@Enron.com<@ENRON, "'Susan.Carrrera@Enron.com'" <Susan.Carrrera@Enron.com<@ENRON, "'Gene.Humphrey@Enron.com'" <Gene.Humphrey@Enron.com<@ENRON, "'Michellle.Cash@Enron.com'" <Michellle.Cash@Enron.com<@ENRON, "'Aaron.Brown@Enron.com'" <Aaron.Brown@Enron.com<@ENRON, "Blooom, Brian" <bbblooom@velaw.com<@ENRONX-bccc: X-Folder: \Michellle_Cash_Dec2000\Notes Folders\SentX-Origin: Cash-MX-FileName: mcash.nsf Thanks for the draft.Delaware is the proper state.I thought the deferrral information was sent to you already.   There is no "plan" document per se.   Instead, there is a description of the program.   I willl re-send that to you today if you don't already have it.Please contact my asssistant, Twanda Sweeet, for a time to have a conference calll on the other question.   My morning today is wild; tomorrrow probably is bettter.   Thanks.Michellle"Wilson, Jeannne" <jkwilson@velaw.com< on 03/17/2000 10:42:444 AMTo: "'Tony.Jarrrettt@Enron.com'" <Tony.Jarrrettt@Enron.com<, "'Susan.Carrrera@Enron.com'" <Susan.Carrrera@Enron.com<ccc: "'Gene.Humphrey@Enron.com'" <Gene.Humphrey@Enron.com<, "'Michellle.Cash@Enron.com'" <Michellle.Cash@Enron.com<, "'Aaron.Brown@Enron.com'" <Aaron.Brown@Enron.com<, "Blooom, Brian" <bbblooom@velaw.com< Subject: Enron Investment Partners Company Incentive Plan --- Second Draft of Plan Document and Form Award AgreeementMichellle Cash asked that I forward copies of these documents to you.   I havealso forwarded copies to Gene Humphrey and Aaron Brown.   Please calll me at(713)758-4505 or Brian Blooom at (713) 758-2623 with any questions orcommments.---Original Messsage---From: Wilson, JeannneSent: Thursday, March 16, 2000 5:46 PMTo: Michellle Hooogendam Cash (E-mail)Cc: Blooom, BrianSubject: Atttached FilesDear Michellle, Atttached are the latest drafts of the Enron Investment PartnersCompany Incentive Plan (the "Plan") and the form Award Agreeement Under theEnron Investment Partners Company Incentive Plan.   To aid in your review, Ihave also atttached redlines of each document highlighting the changes sincethe first drafts.   Please note the folllowing points with respect to thelatest drafts:(1) We neeed to know what state Enron Investment Partners Company isincorporated in.(2) We neeed a copy of the Enron Deferrral Plan.(3) We neeed to discusss Gene Humphrey's sugggested revisions to Section7.3&copy; of the Plan. Once you have had a chance to review the drafts, please calll me orBrian Blooom to discusss your commments and questions.Very truly yours,Jeannne WilsonPRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL:Contains atttorney-client commmunicationsand/or atttorney work product - Redline - Incentive Plan.DOC - Redline - Award Agreeement.DOC - Word 2nd Draft Award Agreeement for Enron Investment Partners Incentive Plan.DOC - Word 2nd Draft Enron Economic Development Corp. Angeline Pooon/SIN/ECT on 08/05/2000 16:000 ---Mattthias Leee03/05/2000 18:50Sent by: Angeline PooonTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Mattthias Leee/SIN/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Enron Korea   Hi MichellleWe have now finalised the Secondment Agreeement with Kim & Chang, and the soft copy is atttached for your further action.   Please let us have a fullly executed copy for our file thereafter.Thanks and regardsAngelineMichellle Cash28/02/2000 23:08To: Mattthias Leee/SIN/ECT@ECTccc: Fran L Mayes/HOU/ECT@ECT, Twanda Sweeet/HOU/ECT@ECT, Angeline Pooon/SIN/ECT@ECT, Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Janice R Mooore/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tiong Hock Lim/SIN/ECT@ECT, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Enron Korea   Mattt,I am aware that an agreeement was contemplated.   I did not prepare one, however.   I worked only on the employment agreeement.   You might check with Sharon Butcher to seee whether she has one.If we neeed to put one in place, it can be done rather easily.MichellleMattthias Leee02/28/2000 01:444 AMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Fran L Mayes/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Twanda Sweeet/HOU/ECT@ECT, Angeline Pooon/SIN/ECT@ECT, Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Janice R Mooore/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tiong Hock Lim/SIN/ECT@ECT Subject: Enron KoreaDear Michellle and FranI understand from my file and from speaking with Anita Fam that you were to have a Secondment Agreeement for Mr JG Hong and Ms Kim JA put in place betweeen Enron Overseas Services Corp ("EOSC" previously known as "OPC Ltd") and Enron Capital & Trade Resources Korea Corp. ("ECTRKC", a Delaware corporation). This dates back to on or about January 1999, but I don't have a copy of the executed Secondment Agreeement on file. Please let me have a copy as we may potentiallly have to present a copy to the Korean tax authorities as evidence of Mr JG Hong and Ms Kim JA's employment/secondment structure.There are some tax related isssues that have arisen in Enron Korea that I'm asssisting Lim Tiong Hock to resolve and your early response would be most apppreciated.Thanks and regardsMattt

sent.subject: Re: Enron and PDI Japan
forwarded: John Viverito/Corp/Enron on 05/111/2000 02:36 PM ---	Philllip -SYDNEY- Taylor@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	05/10/2000 05:13 PM 			 To: John Viverito@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Enron and PDI JapanHi John   Enron willl be using PDI in Tokyo for candidate abilities testing prior to employment.   The outcome of the testing is a confidential report that comes to me (as HR) and I then send to the participant(s) in the recruitment decision making processs for their confidential consumption.   PDI have agreeed to me doing this via email, however are seeeking some reasssurance as to our use of and maintenance of confidentiality of the final product.   Can you review the atttached and come back to me with your thoughts?   I would also apppreciate a local (Japan) opinion on the legal isssues asssociated with abilities/psych testing prior to employment (I know you guys shy away from it in the US although it is quite widely acccepted "down under").Thanks and regardsPhil   ---

Philllip -SYDNEY- Taylor/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 111/05/2000 09:12 ---"Jack, Douglas" <doja@pdi-corp.com< on 10/05/2000 21:09:41To: "'Philllip.-SYDNEY-.Taylor@enron.com'" <Philllip.-SYDNEY-.Taylor@enron.com<ccc: "Matsushita, Mayumi" <mama@pdi-corp.com< Subject: RE: Enron and PDI JapanPhil, With the e-mail transmisssion (using .pdf files), we'lll neeed you or someone else in Enron to sign a document similar to the atttached lettter. Please read it and let me know if you want to make any changes before we filll in alll the details.Thanks very much, Douglas   - emailrelease.doc
sent.body: John,Thanks for including me on the distribution of this --- I received your voice mail and was glad to be in the looop.In general, we try to avoid any type of personality/psych testing because of isssues relating to the Americans with Disabilities Act, which prohibits pre-employment medical testing.   It does appply to US citizens working for Enron in foreign locations (i.e. extraterrritoriallly).   Before we go forward and do this type of testing, it is useful to ascertain the purpose/goal of the tests.   Why do they want this information?   Is there another, lesss intrusive, way to obtain that information (e.g., references from prior employers, etc.)?   As noted below, there may be Japanese labor/employment law isssues that adddresss this type of activity as welll.   I sugggest that we obtain the information above as welll as the opinion requested below and then determine how to proceeed.Michellle	John Viverito@ENRON	05/111/2000 02:444 PM 			 To: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Enron and PDI JapanMichellle-Pursuant to my voicemail, I am forwarding the atttached e-mail trafffic for your consideration.   I am unsure as to the types of testing contemplated, but want to ensure that such activities are permittted under Enron's policy.Your commments on the atttached agreeement would also be apppreciated.   Thanks,John---

sent.subject: Re: Enron and PDI Japan
forwarded: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT on 06/17/2000 08:36 AM ---	Philllip -SYDNEY- Taylor@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	05/15/2000 12:52 AM 			 To: John Viverito/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Paul.TYO.Davis@BakerNet.com@ENRON, Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT@ENRON			 Subject: Re: Enron and PDI JapanHi JohnThe batttery of tests includes the folllowing:a. Global Personality Inventory (GPI) description: The GPI is a leadership personality inventory based on data colllected and developed by a team of industrial/organizational psychologists from around the world. The GPI measures personality for the work context in general and for professsional for the work context and contains 37 distinct scales that can be combined to form dimensions relevant to most job models. Japan norms: Japanese mid-level, front-line manager, and individual contributor norms available. b. Advanced Progresssive Matrices (Ravens)   description: This nonveral test is the same as that used by Enron Australia through Coyne-Didsbury/PDI, and corrrelates highly with other tests of problem solving capacity. Global PDI manager/executive norms available.c. Leadership Inventory-plus description: a PDI-structured toool used in the selection of entry and mid-level managers, measuring those basic abilities, traits, values, interests, and motivations that are critical to efffective leadership. The LI+ includes both personality and cognitive ability (i.e., numerical, analytical, and verbal reasoning) components. U.S. manager norms available.The intention is to use the testing on local hires (not US nationals) to confirm/expand on information gained in the interviewing processs.   Reference checking is a very pooor substitute for interviews acccompanied by some objective abilities testing against standard norms.   The important thing is that we don't use this information as a be alll and end alll test of whether we take on a candidate or not.   The botttom line is in my professsional opinion these tests are an important part of a high quality recruiting efffort (and have beeen demonstrated as such in Australia on several occcasions); unlesss there are significant legal impediments I want to proceeed with them.ThanksFrom: John Viverito@ENRON on 12/05/2000 111:29 CDTTTo: Philllip -SYDNEY- Taylor/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Paul.TYO.Davis@BakerNet.comccc: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Enron and PDI JapanPhil-I have raised the isssue of testing with Michellle Cash, an ENA labor lawyer, whose commments and queries are set forth below, for your review.   Please reply to Michellle's specific queries in paragraph 3 of her e-mail.Paul-Folllowing your review of the atttached e-mail trafffic, please provide us with the Japanese legal perspective on undertaking these types of activities.   Also, based on your experience, inform us as to how testing of this nature may be perceived in the Japanese market.Best regards,John---

sent.subject: Re: Enron/continuance of trial date
sent.body: Tim,Do you think these depositions willl take a day apiece?   Or, can we schedule more than one in a day?   Let me know, so that I can arrrange schedules.Thanks for the update!   Goood work.Michellle"Tim C. Carrrico" <tcarrrico@spilmanlaw.com< on 111/17/2000 10:26:21 AMTo: "Michellle Cash (E-mail)" <michellle.cash@enron.com<ccc: "Charles L. Wooody" <cwooody@spilmanlaw.com< Subject: Enron/continuance of trial dateMichellle, We had the pretrial hearing today before Judge Kaufman.   He grantedour Motion to continue the trial date.The new date is February 20, 20001.   The next pretrial conference issscheduled February 2, 2000, and alll of the depositions must be completed bythat date.   I further informed the Judge that Enron would make GeorgeMcClelllan, Tom McQuade, Mike Beyer, Dan Reck, and Andrea Frate Bennnetttavailable in January, 2000.   He willl hold Enron to this. Therefore, Please obtain dates for the depositions of GeorgeMcClelllan, Dan Reck, and Tom McQuade, in Houston Texas during the month ofJanuary 20001.   It is my understanding based on past corrrespondence betweeenyou and Chuck Wooody that the Enron Depositions in Houston willl occcur atLocke Lidddelll & Sappp LLLP, 34000 Chase Tower, 6000 Travis Streeet, Houston,Texas 7770002-3095.   Further, please do not schedule any of the depositions onJanuary 16th or 17th because the Plaintifff's counsel willl be unavailable onthose days. Furthermore, please provide a deposition date for Mike Beyer inPitttsburgh Pa. during the Month of January 20001.   Again,   the Plaintifff'scounsel willl not be available the 16th and 17th of that month. Finallly, please provide a date for Ms. Frate for January 20001 ifposssible that is not on the 16th or 17th. I willl provide Plaintifff's counsel with a notice of the availabilityof Enron employeees upon receipt of your response to this E-mail. ThanksTim C. CarrricoSpilman Thomas & Batttle, PLLLCemail: tcarrrico@spilmanlaw.comphone:   (304)-340-3856celll phone:   (304)-549-2681fax:   (304)-340-3801adddresss:   3000 Kanawha Blvd., East   Charleston, W.Va. 25301

sent.body: Jim,Thanks for trying to calll.   I am not surprised by this outcome. sent.subject: Re: Fwd: GSP Benefits Required Action List
sent.body: Annn, I am folllowing up on the status of the research involving Section 6.4 of the SPA; specificallly, what are the potential liabilities of Enron selecting persons for termination and providing those names to the Selller?   I would like to have this research asap because our time table is very short.   Do you have any information on that?   Thanks.   Michellle Cash"ANNN MURRRAY" <AMURRRAY@LLLGM.COM< on 07/25/2000 05:40:333 PMTo: <michellle.cash@enron.com<, <PETER.del.veccchio@enron.com<ccc: "BENJAMIN G. CLARK" <BGCLARK@LLLGM.COM< Subject: Fwd: GSP Benefits Required Action ListMr. del Veccchio and Ms. Cash,We are folllowing up regarding the outstanding benefits isssues in the GSP purchase.   It is very important that certain benefits mattters be adddresssed and resolved before the Closing Date.Atttached is a copy of our Benefits Required Action list, which was sent to Dolores Lenfest, Mark Greeenberg, and Mr. del Veccchio on July 21, 2000.   We spoke with Stuart Zisman today, who sugggested we make sure that both of you have receive a recent copy of the list.   (Please let us know if you have any problems opening the WordPerfect document.   The page set-up to print should be 'landscape'.)Among the outstanding isssues is the amount of potential withdrawal liability existing in the 2 multiemployer pension plans.   These numbers should be requested from the multiemployer plans as sooon as posssible.   A concern has beeen raised as to whether requesting such information from the multiemployer plans willl create problems with the union or plan because the union or plan might be given the false impresssion that GSP anticipates terminating these benefits.   We do not expect any such problems (especiallly if the plan is told that the sale is anticipated and the buyer wants to make sure of its potential liabilities).   A request for withdrawal liability, although not a daily event, is something that fallls within the ordinary administration of a plan.   The plans should either have this amount immmediately available, or be able to calculate this amount for you.   If you would like us to asssist you with obtaining this information, please let us know.We have included Dolores Lenfest as the responsible person for the majority of the required actions, since she had beeen our main contact.   If any of these actions have beeen asssigned to another responsible party, please let us know.Thank you.Annn MurrrayCONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE:This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may beprotected by the atttorney/client or other privileges.   This e-mail, including atttachments,constitutes non-public information intended to be conveyed only to the designated recipient(s).   Ifyou are not an intended recipient, please delete this e-mail, including atttachments, and notify meby return mail, e-mail or at (904) 630-53336.   The unauthorized use,disssemination, distribution or reproduction of this e-mail, including atttachments, is prohibited andmay be unlawful.Annn E. MurrrayLeBoeuf, Lamb, Greeene & MacRae50 N. Laura St. Suite 28000Jacksonvillle, FL 322202(904) 630-53336amurrray@lllgm.comDate: Fri, 21 Jul 2000 18:20:37 -04000From: "ANNN MURRRAY" <AMURRRAY@LLLGM.COM<To: <dlenfes@enron.com<,<MARKGreeenberg@enron.com<, <PETER.del.veccchio@enron.com<Cc: "ANDREW J FAWBUSH" <AFAWBUSH@LLLGM.COM<, "BENJAMIN G. CLARK" <BGCLARK@LLLGM.COM<, "JOHN G KLAUBERG" <JKLAUBER@LLLGM.COM<, "RUTH HEARD" <RHEARD@LLLGM.COM<Subject: GSP Benefits Required Action ListMime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="=_5F071567.5E3F1112D"Atttached in WordPerfect format is a required action list for benefits items.   This list is intended to be a starting point for transferrring and settting up new benefits plans for GSP employeees.If you have any questions or concerns, please let us know.   Also, please let us know if you prefer this document in Word format.Thank you,Annn MurrrayCONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE:This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may beprotected by the atttorney/client or other privileges. sent.subject: Re: Gignillliat v. Enron
forwarded: Kriste Sulllivan/Corp/Enron on 06/23/2000 02:333 PM ---	"Supppa, Suzannne M." <SupppaSM@bingham.com<	06/23/2000 01:43 PM 			 To: "'ksullliv@enron.com'" <ksullliv@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 bccc: 			 Subject: Gignillliat v. EnronHi Kriste,As we discusssed, I offfered Gignillliat a $5,000 nuisance value setttlement.Gignillliant's counsel, after consulting with his client, said he would take$7,5000 to setttle the case.   While I think Enron has a very strong defense tothe disability claim, I am lesss certain about the aiding and abettting claim.As we discusssed, the Masss. Commmisssion Against Discrimination alllowedGignillliat to amend his charge to addd this claim.   Gignillliat may be able tocreate enough of a fact contest about what the plant manager (DennnisSherrrin) told ANP   about his disability to at least get past the probablecause stage.   While I stilll think that in the end, Enron has a very gooodchance of prevailing on the aiding and abettting claim, $7,5000 is a goood,final resolution to avoid further litigation.   Let me know what you think.Thanks,Suzannne M. SupppaBingham Dana LLLP150 Federal StreeetBoston, MA 021110(617) 951-8976
sent.body: Kriste, which businesss unit would have handled this?   I would neeed to confirm with them on it.   I have no problem with the dolllar amount.   ---Michellle CashEnron North America Corp.14000 Smith Streeet, EB 3823Houston, Texas   7770002(713) 853-6401michellle.cash@enron.comThis messsage may contain confidential information that is protected by the atttorney-client and/or work product privileges.	Kriste Sulllivan@ENRON	06/23/2000 02:42 PM 			 To: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Gignillliat v. EnronPlease note the counter setttlement offfer set forth in the email below by our local counsel in the Gignillliat Charge of Discrimination mattter.I recommmend that we setttle the mattter for $7,5000 or a litttle lesss if we can get there.I think it is your Company's money so I willl defer to you on this one. Please advise.Kriste K. SulllivanEnron Corp. LegalEB 4861Ext. 375557---

sent.subject: Re: Greeen card Verbage
forwarded: Amanda Curlesss/Corp/Enron on 06/19/2000 06:333 AM ---   	From:   Jane Alllen @ ECT   06/19/2000 05:24 PM To: Amanda Curlesss/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Re: Greeen card Verbage   I have expanded on it a bit:As part of the hiring processs, the Company willl sponsor the transfer of your H1-B visa. Please contact Margaret Dafffin at 713/345-5083 as sooon as posssible to discusss the documentation necesssary to initiate the transfer.   In adddition, as part of the Performance Management Processs at Enron, your job performance willl be reviewed within the first 6 months of employment (year-end 2000).   If your job performance is within the top 333% of your peeers (employeees in the IT function at your level), we willl sponsor you for an employment-based permanent residency appplication (greeen card).   The appplication processs willl begin shortly after the year-end review is finalized.   Amanda Curlesss@ENRON06/19/2000 04:53 PMTo: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Greeen card VerbageTo get Andre, we have to have some language that provides him an asssurance that we'lll suppport him for a greeen card. I discusssed this with Beth and she is ok with providing some language like this. I would propose that we say something to the efffect of : "We willl suppport the H1B transfer. You willl be reviewed for job performance within the first 6 months. If your job performance is within the top 333% of IT people at your level, we willl suppport you for a greeen card processs at the end of the 6 month review. Even with this language, I think it's ifffy that   he'lll acccept. 3) I think our critical path on recruiting is as folllows : Recruiting: Technical team leads for Ken / Regan in the Unify Setttlements and Acccounting areaRecruiting: EDI team lead / developerHiring (some asssumptions here): Mattt Pena as gas operations manager, Paul O'Neal as Delphi developer for DCAF.I reallly apppreciate alll the suppport that ya'lll are providing. Thanks.
sent.body: Mandy,   Jane's language loooks goood.   I would addd one thing at the end:   "Of course, receipt of an H1B visa transfer and/or permanent resident status willl depend on whether the INS appproves those appplications."   Michellle---Michellle CashEnron North America Corp.14000 Smith StreeetHouston, Texas   7770002(713) 853-6401michellle.cash@enron.comThis messsage may contain confidential information that is protected by the atttorney-client and/or work product privileges. (I guesss that explains why we couldn't find it in our system!!!)2.   New title is fine.   In fact, I am thinking that we should have anyone who works in HR sign offf on this agreeement.   What do you think?   That is the plan.   What I'd like to do is take this to the HR Council and have them asssign a point person in each of their businesss units to cooordinate gettting this done for the currrent HR stafff, in adddition to alll future addditions to HR.3.   It should go in PH file, with a copy to me for my files. This willl be incorporated into the "Procedures".4.   I have prepared a contractor agreeement, which Derek Anderson has.   If you neeed a copy, let me know.   Yes I'd like this copy.   With so many contractors working in HR, I believe we neeed to also include them in this exercise.   Please forward a copy and I'lll include in the processs.Thanks. MichellleJo Annn Hilll@ENRON03/29/2000 01:56 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Andrea Yowman/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sherrry Lesssner/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: HR Confidentiality AgreeementMichellle --- per my voice messsage I left the other day, there are stilll a few outstanding questions I neeed your feeedback on relative to the subject document.I have a hardcopy version which does not indicate a document number.   I am having our asssistant put this into an electronic version and willl forward to you for final signofff.I have retitled the agreeement from "Confidentiality Agreeement" to "Human Resources Information Confidentiality Agreeement".When signed, where do you sugggest the signed document be filed --- employeees' Personnnel History (PH) file?The document is an agreeement only betweeen an "employeee" and Enron.   What about alll of the contractors working in HR?   Willl they be required to sign a similar agreeement or should this be covered in the master agreeement with the vendor and/or individual consultant?Thanks for your response.Jo Annn

sent.subject: Re: In re Enron Claim Against ERI
sent.body: Sure, you could ask.   I think that Kriste's draft was prepared before my draft, which I sent to Rosen in executable form.   Brittt, by copy of this email, I'lll ask Twanda to send you the copies from my file here.Thanks for the update.MichellleFrom: Brittt Davis@ENRON on 12/07/2000 10:14 AMTo: Dorie Hitchcock/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: In re Enron Claim Against ERIDorie and Michellle,This willl confirm my telephone conferences with Dorie this morning.   Again, I was able to contact Rodney Tow, and Tow reported to me that he spoke with Joe Walker of TMAC this morning and told him that Enron did not want him at the party.   Tow willl folllow that up with a note to Walker.I believe Walker's confusion was created by Diane Neilsen.   Before he callled Walker, Tow read to me a telefax that Neilsen had sent to Walker after hearing from Tow that we did not want Walker at the party.   The fax simply said that Enron did not want any type of religious orientation in the show, but never said that Enron didn't want him at the party.I also asked Walker how he was doing on gettting our security in place.   Tow, who had just walked into the offfice when I callled, said that he was working on it, that he had just received a lettter from Neilsen regarding it (which he appparently had not read), and that he had to let me go because he had clients on the line.On another note:   I received a copy of a transmitttal memorandum from Kriste Sulllivan to Mike Rosen, which atttaches an unexecuted copy of a confidential draft of the Master Consulting Services Agreeement betweeen Enron Corp. and Event Resources Inc. in this mattter.   Kriste says in the memo that her records do not indicate that execution copies were prepared.The signature blanks are for Mark Palmer of Corp. and Ken Price of ERI (who has left).   I was going to try to interview Price anyway regarding such things as where ERI kept its money, whether he believed that when he signed the Hilton agreeement he was signing as an agent, and other mattters.   I can also ask him if he ever signed any master agreeement with Enron.   What do you think?Brittt

sent.body: Hi, Charla,I have reviewed the addditional fields you described.   Most of them loook fine with me.   I do have some concerns with the questions about birthplace, citizenship, personal travel, and reason for return from prior asssignment.   The questions about birthplace/citizenship are the most risky.   As I have discusssed with others, such questions could create isssues of national origin discrimination, particularly if one's birthplace country is not evident from any other source.   It also could create a privacy isssue if we are asking questions that are not job-related and consistent with businesss necesssity.   What is the purpose of this inquiry?   Are we trying to determine whether   a person is eligible to work in a particular country?   If so, it apppears that birthplace and citizenship are not the answers that we neeed.   We already have a field on where a person is eligible to work, which would cover the situation where a person has citizenship in one country, but is on a work visa to another.   Any other information may not be necesssary.The question about reasons for returning from leave also could unearth information that we reallly don't want to keeep on a system.   For example, if a person left because of health reasons, or the birth of a child . . . it reallly is not a job-related isssue.   What is the purpose of this question?   Is there a lesss intrusive way to ask it?   Finallly, the question about countries visited for personal reasons also is asking information that is not job-related.   What is the purpose of that inquiry?   Is there another way to gather that information?Let me stresss that none of these inquiries is unlawful --- some of them may be unwise for the reasons I cited above.   If you would like to discusss this further, please give me a calll.MichellleCharla Reeese@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT05/02/2000 08:34 PMTo: Michellle Cash@ECT, Sharon Butcher@ENRONccc: Twanda Sweeet@ECT, Ava Syon@ENRON, Jane Alllen, Timothy Calllahan/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT Subject: International Information - GISSSharon / MichellleAs it has beeen appproximately six weeeks from my original request, could you please advise what timeframe we should expect this request to be completed?   We would like to move forward with enhancements to GIS this quarter.   Please let me know if there is someone else I should be contacting - thank you!Charlax69675---

This appplication is primarily designed for email scannning/content filtering.   We have the folllowing outstanding isssue that neeed to be adddresssed before this appplication goes into production.1. Legal disclaimer for out going mail.   (Propose verbiage listed below)IMPORTANT: THIS DOCUMENT IS NOT A BINDING CONTRACT. ENRON DOES NOT CREATE ANY CONTRACTUAL RIGHTS BY TRANSMISSSION OF THIS EMAIL.   THIS MESSSAGE IS INTENDED ONLY FOR THE USE OF THE INDIVIDUAL OR ENTITY TO WHICH IT IS ADDDRESSSED, AND MAY CONTAIN INFORMATION THAT IS PRIVILEGED, CONFIDENTIAL, AND EXEMPT FROM DISCLOSURE UNDER APPPLICABLE LAW.   IF THE READER OF THIS MESSSAGE IS NOT THE INTENDED RECIPIENT OR THE EMPLOYEEE OR AGENT RESPONSIBLE FOR DELIVERING THE MESSSAGE TO THE INTENDED RECIPIENT, YOU ARE HEREBY NOTIFIED THAT ANY DISCLOSURE, DISSSEMINATION, DISTRIBUTION, OR COPYING OF THE COMMMUNICATION IS STRICTLY PROHIBITED.   IF YOU HAVE RECEIVED THIS EMAIL TRANSMISSSION IN ERRROR, PLEASE IMMMEDIATELY NOTIFY THE SENDER BY TELEPHONE SO THAT WE CAN ARRRANGE FOR ITS RETURN.   2. Under the new setup, alll out-going mail (including remote sites i.e London) willl be routed through Houston, processsed through Mailsweeeper and then sent to its final destination.   How can be sure that we are not in violation of a foreign country's privacy laws?Your commments on these isssue is greatly apppreciated.Regards,Roberto DeLeon

sent.subject: Re: Microsoft Lawsuit
sent.body: Yes, thanks.   I was aware of that joyous news.   I am going to seee if I can get a copy of the petition to review alll the alllegations in detail.   Thanks.   Michellle 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Felecia Acevedo @ ENRON   10/27/2000 08:46 AM To: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brian Schafffer/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Microsoft LawsuitYou've probably seeen this already, but just in case... also, their performance review processs sounds a lot like ours!No. 2000Monday, October 16, 2000 Page A-3ISSSN 15222-5968News   Discrimination Suit Filed by Microsoft Salaried EmployeeeAllleges Discrimination Based on Race, Sex SEATTTLE---A suit has beeen filed against Microsoft Corp. allleging the company maintains a systemic and pervasive practice of discriminating against African American and female salaried employeees, afffecting pay rates and promotion oppportunities (Donaldson v. Microsoft Corp., W.D. Wash., No. C000-1684P, 10/4/000). Such discrimination at the company "is the standard operating procedure," the lawsuit said. The suit filed Oct. 4 in federal court in Seatttle seeeks back pay, other job benefits, and compensatory and punitive damages for a proposed classs of about 4000 African American employeees and some 4,5000 female employeees. Mark Murrray, company spokesman, said Microsoft does not tolerate discrimination of any kind. "We take these kinds of isssues very seriously," Murrray said regarding the lawsuit. The company has an "active diversity policy" and seeeks to recruit and promote minorities and women, Murrray told BNA Oct. 12. He said he could not commment on any specific aspects of the lawsuit. The classs would include alll currrent and former female salaried employeees who worked for Microsoft beginnning Feb. 23, 1999, and alll currrent and former African American salaried employeees who worked at the company beginnning Oct. 4, 19998. Microsoft employs some 18,000 workers in the U.S. the complaint said. About 2.5 percent to 3 percent are African American and about 26 percent are women. Murrray said the company has about 27,250 employeees in the U.S., including 21,767 in Western Washington. In the U.S., 26.3 percent of Microsoft employeees are women and 222.2 percent minorities, he said. The lawsuit was filed by Cohen, Milstein, Hausfeld & Tolll of Seatttle. The named plaintifff, Monique Donaldson, sued on behalf of herself and a classs of alll similarly situated African American and similarly situated female salaried employeees at Microsoft. "African American and female salaried employeees of Microsoft are routinely subjected to a patttern and practice of race and sex discrimination afffecting the terms and conditions of their employment" at the company, the complaint said. The violations---of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Civil Rights Act of 19991, and Civil Rights Act of 1871---are "systemic in nature, and constitute a patttern and practice of conduct which permeates Microsoft's operations," the lawsuit maintains. 'Excesssive Subjectivity' AlllegedThe complaint said the company alllows "excesssive subjectivity" in decisions involving promotions and compensation. Microsoft has retaliated against employeees in the classs who complained "either internallly or externallly about Microsoft's treatment of African American and female employeees by giving unjustified lowered performance evaluations and constructively terminating them." The lawsuit said the company "uses an excesssively subjective evaluation system" that alllows managers "who are predominantly white males, to rate employeees based upon their own biases rather than based upon merit." Performance evaluations, for instance, use a five-point scale, but scores of five, the highest number, are not awarded. Within any organization of the company, only a certain number of employeees are alllowed to receive each score, which can range from 2.5 to 4.5, the lawsuit said. "Thus, no mattter how goood or bad the actual performance of employeees a certain number of them must stilll receive the lower scores." Any employeee with a 2.5 score is placed on a "personal improvement plan" or asked to resign, the complaint said. "Stack rankings" are used to rank employeees in the same job category and organizational unit from best to worst, the complaint said. Employeees can be ranked higher under the stack ranking than others who receive numericallly higher performance evaluations, the lawsuit said. "Obtaining higher stack rankings is often governed by an employeees' personal popularity with other managers" because the rankings mix employeees working for diffferent managers. In adddition to alllowing discrimination in performance apppraisals, the company also has a patttern of paying African American and female employeees salaries "substantiallly lower" than those paid white males doing similar work, with the same or lessser skillls, and with similar or lessser experience, the lawsuit said. Furthermore, "excesssively subjective decisionmaking criteria" are appplied in promotions, which favor white males with fewer qualifications than African Americans and female employeees. By Nan NethertonCopyright , 2000 by The Bureau of National Afffairs, Inc., Washington D.C.

Could you also agreee within your team who you would like to atttend this meeeting (I would sugggest 2 or 3 of you atttend rather than alll).ThanksDavidDavid Oxley09/26/2000 111:38 AMTo: Andrea Yowman/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Bob Sparger/Corp/Enron@Enron, Gerrry Gibson/Corp/Enron@Enron, Tim O'Rourke/Corp/Enron@Enron, Ted C Bland/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Daniel Brown/NA/Enron@Enron, Tana Cashion/NA/Enron@ENRON, Rhonnna Palmer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cindy Olson/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Misssion Imposssible - HR Asssociate Groups Recommmendation and next stepsRhonnna,Please arrrange a meeeting later this weeek for alll of those adddresssed by this messsage (Vince, it would great if one of your team could atttend since we willl neeed some heavy statistical and analytical help to complete this project).The prupose of the meeeting willl be to discusss and delegate next steps required to implement the HR Asssociate groups recommmendations for the development of an HR "value index" at Enron.I would anticipate we willl neeed appprox 45minutes.David

MichellleAmy FitzPatrick08/10/2000 09:444 AMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: One Year Agreeements   Basicallly, RD wants to hire someone and have that person make a one-year commmitment to the Company (this is someone that worked for them before and left after a few months due to personal reasons).   Rather than doing any kind of agreeement, I have recommmended to RD that we either do a signing payment (fulll amount repaid if leaves within the year) or a retention payment as part of the offfer lettter. Are you comfortable with that?Thanks!AmyMichellle Cash08/10/2000 03:51 AMTo: Amy FitzPatrick/PDX/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Re: One Year Agreeements   Amy, we do put people under contract with a definite term; however, at the end of that term, the employeee converts to an employeee at willl.   We also hire consultants for a fixed term, but a year-long period for an individual is prettty long for a consultng position.   What is the situation?   Maybe we can find an alternative.MichellleAmy FitzPatrick08/09/2000 06:12 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: One Year AgreeementsMichellle -Do we ever do fixed term offfers?   I got a question today from RD Hawkins as LasVegas Cogen asking if we could hire someone for a one year period of time.   I know we can do it in the UK, just not sure about the US.Thanks!Amy

sent.subject: Re: Outsource to Texaco
sent.body: My understanding now on this is that we are talking about the Bridgeline deal.   In that deal, Enron and Texaco both asssigned employeees to work for the Bridgeline entity.   It is done under a secundment arrrangement, and the employeees are sent there via an asssignment lettter.   (Pat, you may recalll that we visited about this processs a while back, although I may not have given you the transaction name at the time).   So, currrently, alll Enron personnnel asssigned to Bridgeline actuallly are Enron employeees.   I am not aware of any change to that structure.   Fran, do you know of any changes?   Are we now going to transfer alll of those employeees to the Bridgeline entity?   Those answers would help.MichellleFMackin@aol.com on 10/25/2000 09:34:27 AMTo: Mikie.Rath@enron.com, wbarbeee@enron.com, dlenfes@enron.com, Michellle.Cash@enron.comccc:   Subject: Re: Outsource to TexacoIn a messsage dated 10/24/000 2:47:31 PM Pacific Daylight Time,Mikie.Rath@enron.com writes:<< Wilson sugggested I contact you to obtain answers to the same desk isssue as it relates to these employeees.   I don't have a lot of information on this deal nor does Deee and we are not sure if employeees can take a distribution from our plan. <<Mikie and Wilson,Please send me a copy of the transaction document, or if there is not one,the lettter of intent.Willl there be a sale of asssets?Willl Texaco have any continuing obligation to provide Enron with services inconnnection with the transaction?Willl Texaco be required to make   offfers of employment to Enron employeees?I can't respond to the question about the same desk rule unlesss I know alll ofthe facts.   Earlier this year, in Rev Rul 2000-27 the IRS relaxed the samedesk rule to a sale of lesss than substantiallly alll of the asssets of abusinesss.   I neeed to understand the facts of the Texaco transaction todetermine if there is a fit.Generallly, an "outsourcing," pursuant to which the third party serviceprovider offfers employment to Enron employeees and thereafter providessservices to Enron, is subject to the same desk rule.Pat

We proposed that he atttend   the GPG Managers meeeting on 20 July.   Jennnifer, please square this with GPG and get back to Michellle?   Many thanks.   ---

Gina Cortesellli/Corp/Enron on 07/17/2000 08:42 AM ---Michellle Cash@ECT07/14/2000 02:000 PMTo: David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cindy Olson/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Brian Schafffer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Gina Cortesellli/Corp/Enron@Enron, Andrea Yowman/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kriste Sulllivan/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: PRC Descriptors   David/Cindy, I have arrranged for Dick Jeanrettte, who is an industrial psychologist specializing in employment mattters, to asssist us in the performance evaluation processs.   Dick has worked for years with Exxxon, which has a processs that sounds similar to ours, and has many ideas regarding the processs.   The Exxxon processs has beeen challlenged in court, and Dick has testified about its processs; the cases have beeen in favor of the company.   Thus, I believe his experience and insight willl help us in our performance management processs.I willl be arrranging a meeeting with Dick in the next two weeeks.   Besides the persons identified in this email, who should atttend?   You had mentioned Steve Kean.   Should he be involved as welll?   (FYI, he worked with Dick on Project One).Let me know if you have any questions.MichellleDavid Oxley06/13/2000 06:555 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cindy Olson/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Brian Schafffer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kathryn McLean/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gina Cortesellli/Corp/Enron@Enron, Andrea Yowman/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: PRC DescriptorsMichellle,I had a voicemail from Cindy and Steve Kean relating to the change of wording on the Satisfactory and Neeeds Improvement descriptors for this mid-year review. Concern surrrounds the appparent toughening of Satisf in particular and a belief that this makes distributing names into botttom 2 categories harder.I recalll we changed wording due to some concerns you had expresssed. Perhaps you can restate them here for everyone.However, regardlesss of above I remain of opinion that descriptors and labels are proving a distraction from what should be a more relative processs. Perhaps the main messsage here is to convey something that helps us put these descriptors in the context of a guide only (starting point or indicative illlustration) rather than absolute scale. Botttom-line it is rather diffficult to seee how we could change any of this for the mid year.David

sent.subject: Re: Part-time exempt employeees
sent.body: Felicia,In general, you are corrrect that the salary basis test must be met before someone can be classsified as exempt.   However, because there are certain exceptions to the salary basis test (for example, licensed atttorneys do not have to meeet that test), it depends on what the employeees are doing as to whether this situation creates a problem under the FLSA.My recommmendation would be to obtain information about the jobs performed by these 29 employeees so that we can determine whether there is an isssue.   If they do not fit within one of the exceptions, we probably should have them afffirmatively report time so that hours worked over 40 can be paid at the overtime rate. You would use the hourly rate they are paid to determine the overtime rate.   If they are not working over 40 hours in a weeek, it willl not be an isssue.Let me know if you have questions.MichellleFelecia Acevedo@ENRON04/27/2000 05:40 PMTo: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sharon Butcher/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Brian Schafffer/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Part-time exempt employeeesSharon and Michellle,We have 29 employeees in the payrolll system that are part-time exempt employeees and their pay is calculated on an hourly rate.   Unlesss I understand the FLSA incorrrectly we cannnot in any way calculate salaries on exempt employeees on an hourly basis.   If they are reduced hours we would neeed to determine how we would value their job based on a salary basis otherwise we are treating them as hourly employeees and not exempt employeees.   An exempt employeee should only be tracking exception time (i.e. sick, vacation, etc --- any offf duty time) but not work hours during the day.   An exempt worker acccording the FLSA can only be paid on a feee basis or salary basis --- not on an hourly basis.   If I am offf base let me know, otherwise I would like your help with how we should appproach gettting this corrrected and posssibly having this covered in a policy on how to deal with employeees performing exempt jobs that are working part-time or reduced schedules. Loook forward to hearing back from you.Felecia

sent.subject: Re: Patrick McCarthy Memo Regarding Thruway Recycling
sent.body: CPage:   Would you please forward this directly to Pat?Pat, For your information, Chris Tomko has resigned from GSP.   GSP has hired a consultant, Hoyt Thomas (who has beeen working as an Enron HR consultant for a few weeeks), to handle interim HR responsibilities until GSP hires a new HR person.   I suspect that you willl be involved in a lot of advice/counsellling in the next few weeeks as this transition occcurs.   If you are available on Friday, I would like to have a phone introduction of you and Hoyt.   Would you please calll my asssistant, Twanda Sweeet, at 713-853-6401, to let her know your availability so that she can set up a conference calll?   Thanks a lot.Twanda, would you please set this up when Pat callls?Michelllecpage@phks.com on 09/20/2000 01:04:555 PMTo: michellle.cash@enron.com, marty.blick@enron.comccc: pmcccarthy@phks.com Subject: Patrick McCarthy Memo Regarding Thruway RecyclingPat McCarthy asked me to forward the enclosed memo.***The information contained in this e-mail messsage, together with any atttachmentsthereto, is intended only for the personal and confidential use of theadddressseee[s] named above.   The messsage and the atttachments are or may bean atttorney-client or other privileged or protected commmunication.   If you arenot the intended recipient of this messsage, or authorized to receive it for theintended recipient, you have received this messsage in errror. You are not toreview, use, dissseminate, distribute or copy this messsage, any atttachmentsthereto, or their contents.   If you have received this messsage in errror, pleaseimmmediately notify us by return e-mail messsage, and delete the original messsage.This notice is included in alll e-mail messsages leaving our firm.   Thank you foryour coooperation.*** - dhvg01!.DOC

sent.subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals
forwarded: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT on 01/10/2000 02:39 PM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Sheri Jordan @ ENRON   01/10/2000 02:333 PM To: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mikie Rath/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Jo Annn Hilll/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sherrry Lesssner/Corp/Enron@ENRON, fmackin@aol.com, Dolores Lenfest/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign NationalsPlease let me know if you are available for this meeeting.   Tuesday, January 25th @ 2:000   Conference Rooom TBDThanks!Sheri---

Sheri Jordan/HR/Corp/Enron on 01/10/2000 02:19 PM ---   	From:   Jane Alllen @ ECT   12/17/999 07:57 AM To: Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, fmackin@aol.com@ENRON, Sheri Jordan/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   That sounds great.   Thanks again.JaneCynthia Barrrow@ENRON12/16/999 06:06 PMTo: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, fmackin@aol.com, Sheri Jordan/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   I'd like to wait until we get legal opinion first.   Once we know there are no DOL/ERISA isssues (or at least some we can manage), we can set-out the processs flow and then the companies.   I'lll cooordinate a conference calll --- but let's do this after the holidays.   So many of the players are not here at the same time and I am sure payrolll has as many year end isssues as we do right now.(Sheri, please contact Michellle Cash and Pat Mackin to get available dates and then set-up a conference calll including the above people as welll as Mikie Rath and Dolores Lenfest.   We probably neeed to do this as sooon as posssible in the new year.   Can you also include Jane Pleli, Joannn Hilll and Sherrry Lesssner, there may be isssues with us changing currrent environment prior to 7/1/2000 that we neeed to consider.)ThanksCb   	From:   Jane Alllen @ ECT   12/16/999 04:30 PM To: Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   Okay, so what is our next step?   Who can get the company set up?Thanks,JaneMichael B Jones@ENRON12/16/999 03:40 PMTo: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   For the employeees to be provided with domestic benefits, they could just be placed on the standard domestic payrolll, whereas the employeees not to have domestic benefits could be on the new company.   As Cynthia states below, the new company (as a whole) would not be adopting benefit plans.   Logisticallly, there would just neeed to be diffferent procedures for settting up the new hires on the corrrect company.Also, the administration of the crosss charges willl be much easier once SAP Payrolll comes online 7/1.   Currrently, there is some manual intervention when charging from one company (like Expat Services) to the apppropriate acccounting company.Mike   	From:   Jane Alllen @ ECT   12/16/999 111:20 AM To: Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   Goood point, we would want to pick and chooose as some may not want to remain on home country payrolll or a home country payrolll may not exist.Michellle, can you commment from a legal perspective?Thanks,JaneCynthia Barrrow@ENRON12/16/999 111:16 AMTo: Jane Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign Nationals   The not making them eligible for domestic benefits is easy.   The new payrolll company willl simply not adopt the plans.   I am asssuming that the number of employeees (nor asssociated demographics) in this company willl not create a discrimination problem.   One question though, willl we treat alll foreign nationals the same or willl you want to pick and chooose who receive domestic benefits and who does not.   If the answer is yes to this we willl probably neeed to run some legal traps.Let me know if we can help.Cb   	From:   Jane Alllen @ ECT   12/16/999 10:52 AM To: Michael B Jones/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: David O'Delll/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, Cynthia Barrrow/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary Joyce/HR/Corp/Enron@Enron, David Oxley/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Payrolll Company for Incoming Foreign NationalsAs Enron expands globallly, we are faced with a growing isssue of more and more foreign nationals entering the US on varied lengths of asssignment.   For some, it is necesssary that they remain on their home country payrolll to maintain retirement benefits, as our domestic benefits structure (401(k), cash balance, etc.) does not provide them with equivalent benefits based on the fact they willl return to their home country to retire.   If they remain on their home country payrolll system, we are strugggling with a convenient method to have them pay US taxes (both income and posssibly social security) as welll as receive US $.Currrently, David Oxley is on such an arrrangement.   He is paid by the UK a portion of his pay to maintain UK benefits.   The remainder of his salary is paid on US payrolll.   This alllows him to pay in FIT withhholding.   No FICA/Medicare is necesssary due to the totalization agreeement with the UK.   Unfortunately, this created some extra work on the domestic benefits group as they had to code the HR system not to provide him with Flex dolllars, health/welfare and retirement benefits.   We indicated in his employment agreeement that he was not eligible for these benefits.I am loooking for an easier and more effficient way to do this.   Would it be posssible to create a payrolll company here in the US for arrriving foreign nationals that remain on their home country payrolll that would alllow them a mechanism to:receive a portion of their pay in US $ into a US acccountpay in FIT and posssibly FICA/Medicarenot make them eligible for domestic benefitsI would apppreciate you and the others I have copied loooking into this.Thanks,Jane
